text: That same complexity (or cost of two languages) also exists in individual software projects, and in ecosystems. Not to mention the personal cost of having to learn a language if you don't want to. How many orgs do you know who use Perl and Python side by side, together when necessary?

I think Perl and Python is a bit of an extreme example :slightly_smiling_face:

Also, I’m curious about how people find the learning curve for Julia from Python. I only ever had Python experience and it took me a month or so before I was comfortable using Julia. Of course, it took me significantly longer before I was _really_ confident in my understanding - but it’s not like you’re moving from Python to Rust.

text: I found the learning curve pleasant. Like you, I only had Python experience. When going from Python, there is a lot to learn, about compilers and type stability and inference, etc., but Julia allows you to learn this gradually. I had a long period (maybe 3 months or so) where I probed Julia without really learning it, but when I started learning it, it took only a few weeks to write my first package. Looking back, of course, the package was horribly inefficient and unidiomatic. I would guess it took me about 1.5 or 2 years after that to instictively write idiomatic Julia.
